While I like the ease of flipping through, there are some issues with how the app works, or the overall rules of the app. The part about people just disappearing. While I understand females want easy outs, I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs necessary to make it that easy. It basically just turns this into a ghost fest, where you never know how long until they disappear. Also the swiping doesn‚Äôt always seem to take, I find myself seeing the exact profile seconds after swiping it once. 
Also, the super swipes don‚Äôt really seem to do anything. Why are they there? And why do we pay more for them when it doesn‚Äôt mean I can actually talk to the person I super swiped? 
Being able to write more in my profile would be nice.
title: Restrictions are too much

review: Most of the people on here don‚Äôt actually live in the state they claim they live in. I see a lot of MI-IL-OK on travel mode. That seems extremely suspicious to me, makes it hard to take them seriously, and I don‚Äôt trust any of them. I can‚Äôt find anyone near me either, despite having put 60 miles max. 300 miles is not that max. I‚Äôm tired of having to pay money just to see who likes me. I also think it‚Äôs ridiculous that women have to reach out first. Why can‚Äôt men have that option too? Also, why is there a time limit for when people can respond to either other? We‚Äôre busy, we should be able to get back to the person in our time, not according to an app. Overall it‚Äôs just a money making app. Don‚Äôt waste your time!

review:
It‚Äôs been about 3 months since I dated last (pandemic life). I decided to jump on Bumble because I remember the caliber of women are higher on this platform. But I went into this experiment unemotional. Post good quality photos, some in groups, others in activities, with a couple of professional shots from a family shoot last year.

I filled out all of the prompts giving thoughtful , interesting responses, and connected my IG. Then I paid for premium to get all the perks. 

In a month, I‚Äôve gotten 4 matches. Only 1 actually started a conversation and left it hanging. The ‚Äúlikes‚Äù I received were bottom of the barrel.

I spent at least an hour daily swiping, reacting, and sending super likes. I am tall, average body type, dress well, average to better than average looks, good job, no fishing pics, no shirtless selfies. 

Bumble like every other app presents itself as the dating app that empowers women. Unfortunately, women don‚Äôt like making the first move proven by the dozens if not hundreds of bios that say so explicitly. Add to that that the men on the app swipe right willy nilly and you get women who are overwhelmed and don‚Äôt want to start thoughtful conversations (gathered from the half dozen or so close female friends I‚Äôve talked to about dating apps)
title: Bumble isn‚Äôt interested in getting you a Date

We really appreciate you taking the time to leave us your feedback about this, and we'll be sure to share it with our Product Team.", 'modified': '2022-08-24T17:21:16Z'}
review:
I‚Äôve been using Bumble on & off for a few years - here‚Äôs what you should know:

* From what I can tell, about 80% of the profiles are ‚Äúinactive.‚Äù That is, someone set it up, used it for while, deleted the app but not their profile. Bumble does NOT delete profiles, even after whenever created it disappeared years ago. 

* I would say if the remaining 15% of profiles, the person checks it maybe once a month or so, which means that whomever has swiped on them has also gone missing.

* Since women make the first move (I wonder how that works in people seeking same-sex relationships), even after ‚Äúmatching,‚Äù the match ‚Äúexpires‚Äù about 90% of the time. The remaining 10% will carry on a few single word answers (‚ÄúHi!‚Äù) and then disappear.

The problem with Bumble, like all the other dating apps, is there there is no transparency or accountability. There is no way of knowing whether a profile is ‚Äúactive,‚Äù if the person logs in regularly, or whether they are interested in anything more than ‚Äúlooking to see who‚Äôs out there.‚Äù

If you don‚Äôt pay for any of the services and check it daily, you have about a 1% chance of success.
title: It‚Äôs online dating, so you know it‚Äôs going to be a train wreck

review: Have not heard back from customer service twice now in the last 6 months. I have had my Bumble for YEARS and it wants me to go through security questions and security texts again. Fine, whatever you need. It‚Äôs been awhile since I‚Äôve been on; I get it. I DO NOT use FB anymore. It is deactivated!! I have zero intentions of activating that toxic garbage again. I have been off of FB now for 7 years! Now, Bumble is saying if I do not sign into my FB to authenticate my app I will lose my matches and convos. Huh? I‚Äôve emailed them from the email I signed up with, I‚Äôve passed their text message security with the same phone number I signed up with and the same one I had at 16 years old in 1999. What more do you want? Why should I be forced to have to use FB in connection with your app? I sent them an email‚Ä¶two e-mails‚Ä¶no response on how to resolve this.

title: Needs work PLEASE

review:
Bumble is consistently the worst of the major dating apps on the market. 

User base:
In all the years I‚Äôve had Bumble, I‚Äôve gotten I think two matches, and one of them never even responded. For example: right now I supposedly have 26 likes (I don‚Äôt pay for the app), but despite all the right swiping I do, I haven‚Äôt had a match in so long I‚Äôve lost track of time. Even when I had a paid subscription, only one of all my matches actually messaged me. I understand the gimmick is to let the girl message first, but in my experience most girls don‚Äôt message first so the whole point of the app is a drawback 

User interface:
Standard tinder ripoff, but the swipe function is so ludicrously sensitive that I often accidentally swipe just because of the way I‚Äôm holding the phone. 

User experience:
I get daily notifications from Bumble, usually multiple a day, and it gets very annoying. I like that prompts are an option but a significant number of profiles don‚Äôt answer any of them and are usually only a couple words.

Summary:
Inactive/unresponsive users, annoying amount of notifications, almost no matches despite almost daily notifications that I have a new like, all in all just a frustrating disappointment
title: Worst of the popular dating apps

Please send us a message at http://bumble.com/contact, so you can check this with our Support Team. üíõ", 'modified': '2023-02-17T17:58:17Z'}
review:
This is an app for singles who just can‚Äôt get enough spam about astrology, but also want to dabble in dating.

You‚Äôd think that if you chose not to list your star sign on your profile then maybe you‚Äôre not someone who‚Äôd want to be relentlessly flooded with astrology spam. Not so. Astrology marketing *is* the goal for this app ‚Äî you can‚Äôt even opt out of it if you want to. Delete one of Bumble‚Äôs own astrology spambots and you‚Äôll just get another one. Try to block it, and they just keep coming.

For the dating app that it pretends to be‚Ä¶ it has its flaws. Accidental right-swipes and superswipes are much too easy to perform by accident. review: In general, I prefer Bumble more than any other dating app (including Tinder). review: My sister created a joke profile with a selfie, a picture of her TV, and a bio consisting of a couple words. I, as a man on the other hand, put in a lot of effort for my profile. Bumble preys on desperate men and does not honestly represent the odds of even being seen as a man. There is a reason they do not publicly disclose the gender ratio. If you are a guy and struggling on this app, do not take it personally. Go anywhere else to meet women! review:
As a single gal nearing 30 and hoping to find a meaningful relationship that can actually lead to something, I really don‚Äôt like wasting my time. The main reason that bumble appealed to me over other apps was the ability to have 2 advanced filters for the free users. It made my life so much easier knowing I would be picking from a pool of matches that I could actually potentially see a future with, because some things a very serious deal breakers for me.

Taking away the 2 free advanced filters means I have to swipe through soooooo many profiles that I know for a fact will be a dead end for me. And I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm not the only one who feels this way, so I‚Äôll leave my review as it is unless this feature is brought back.

Unfortunately it can be really difficult to keep a positive attitude when you‚Äôve been single for a while and this just makes it even harder. I‚Äôll get excited about a profile and then realize that our political views are at odds and we‚Äôd be fighting constantly. Or they don‚Äôt want kids and I‚Äôm not comfortable ruling that out for myself yet so I know even if they‚Äôre sweet it‚Äôs not worth trying because it won‚Äôt work out long term.

Shame on you bumble.

review: For reference I‚Äôm 32, male, LA-based. I‚Äôve been on the app for 3-4 months now, and while I enjoy certain aspects of it (profile format and ease of use), it really is a giant cash grab. If you‚Äôre ever unsure about a profile, please report them in the app and we'll investigate right away!", 'modified': '2023-04-03T02:20:11Z'}
review:
I have seen a tremendous amount of fake profiles and scammers. I unknowingly gave a guy my number and all of a sudden I started getting scam calls, about 2-3 a day‚Ä¶ 

These profiles usually some main elements. The person is born out of the US, the photos all look semi-professional, and if you pay attention, the backdrop seems to be foreign, also they all have the same verbiage, something like - looking for a person that I can spend the rest of my life with and have a family with - too much like what they think every girl would want to hear. 

Recently, I confronted a person on the site when we matched. I asked him yo explain this scam to me, what is it that you want? My phone number my credit card? What‚Äôs your end game? Oddly, the response was you are so beautiful- how is your day? So, it was either a bot or a person that didn‚Äôt want to address my questions. 

Nevertheless, I have deleted Bumble for
The last time and sent a message to them explaining my experience. 

Please be careful, I don‚Äôt see this on other apps. Don‚Äôt be so quick to give your phone number out and if a profile looks to good to be true then it probably is.
title: Scammers & Fake Profiles

*When swiping, there is no way to put someone on hold. You have to swipe right or left to even see anyone else. Sometimes I wanted to think about it. And knowing that if they swipe back, I only have 24 hours to write to them meant I had to really think about swiping if I had a busy day coming up
* Women always writing first seems like a great idea but it just bites. Once there‚Äôs mutual interest, either person should be able to write
Once you swipe, you can‚Äôt I swipe or see who you swiped on. I accidentally swiped right more than once then felt like a jerk when the person swiped back 
*Deleting your account doesn‚Äôt  cancel your subscription. Probably in the fine print but clearly meant to be a moneymaker. Why not at least a ‚Äúwould you also like to cancel your subscription?‚Äù prompt??? It seems logical that I wouldn‚Äôt want to pay for an account that is cancelled. 
*No customer service number.

title: Used to be better. Everyone I know is deleting it now.

review: Up until a few days ago, I got 40 likes per day which would yield at least 1 match per week on average. They recently lowered that amount to 10 claiming it would encourage more accurate swiping. This is awful!! As a guy we outnumber the girls 9 to 1. If I swipe right on 10 people per day, odds are i won‚Äôt even appear in their feed, let alone getting liked back. This really low like count makes sense in a non swipe system, such as hinge, but on here, it is a terrible choice. I won‚Äôt be using this app anymore, it‚Äôs just a waste of time that won‚Äôt yield results unless you pay 15 dollars a week. Over a hundred dollars a year is not worth it for a dating app. I pay significantly less on other subscriptions and get way more value than this garbage. Get this app if you have hundreds to spare. If you don‚Äôt, don‚Äôt bother with it.

They‚Äôre registered to nobody because we live in Arizona and guns aren‚Äôt registered here. Period. So this app reads all your messages and if you talk about any of our American amendments they‚Äôll call the FBI on you. Bumble is highly against the first amendment. developerResponse: {'id': 39109580, 'body': "We're sorry to hear you haven't heard back from us yet! Your message is important to us, so please rest assured we'll be replying to you shortly. We can't thank you enough for your patience. üíõ", 'modified': '2023-09-25T03:20:47Z'}
review:
It‚Äôs a dating app with some twists, cool. Good luck if you ever need support though. Full of broken promises in the form of extremely long delays between replies, I was promised assistance within 2 business days with a simple account issue. It ended up taking more than a dozen attempts contacting support through their various channels and about a month to get a resolution. I shudder to think what happens to those that face more grave issues, such as those that involve personal safety. 

I used bumble a few years ago and had next to no issues with support then. Anyone would likely have much better support (and maybe even date experiences) using Hinge or another more well staffed competitor.

Bumble, you have become a total joke. I‚Äôd say to spare me the copy and paste response to this but I‚Äôm sure you won‚Äôt üëé

review: Bumble used to be, hands-down the best dating app there was. Pay attention to the dates on the reviews that you read here and you‚Äôll see this trend. Three or four years ago this app was magic. Great system of letting the woman initiate the contact after a mutual match. And LOTS of matches happened. Now (I believe after the same company that owns Tinder acquired Bumble) the app has been ruined. Almost universally, all recent reviews show how bad this app has become. Their algorithm is now seriously tweaked to PREVENT matches, or even to show your profile to anyone else unless and until you pay for extra features, and according to other reviews, even then you still get nothing. Complete waste of time even trying to use this app now. Feels exactly like tinder but with a slightly different UI.

For someone like me, who is very very new to the dating scene, I am genuinely happy that this app exists the way it does. 

In my prior experience with other apps, I have almost always felt anxiety and overwhelmed because there are so many people coming from multiple directions with pick up lines and wanting to meet up within a few lines of conversation. developerResponse: {'id': 32333172, 'body': "We really appreciate you sharing your feedback and we'll be sure sharing it with our Product Team! To make sure you don't miss any matches, head to your in-app settings to turn on your notifications. üíõ", 'modified': '2022-10-01T12:46:44Z'}
review:
Couple main things that bother me about this app..
For starters, give people more than 24 hours. People work, and don‚Äôt get on the app every day or multiple times a day. This is a missed opportunity for meeting someone.
Also, here I read a profile and think I‚Äôd be interested in someone, get down to their location, and they‚Äôre at an airport within my mile range, but live on the other end of the country. There‚Äôs a reason I put a mileage limit on it, I don‚Äôt want a long distance relationship.
Also, if you travel, (because the app tracks your location), you‚Äôll get people within that mile range no matter where you go, instead of keeping it around where you actually live/will want to have a relationship.
Because of these reasons, this app isn‚Äôt worth using, in my opinion. It‚Äôs a good initial idea, but the people I matched with, I may have missed an opportunity because they weren‚Äôt on every day. Again, people work, have kids to take care of, etc. 
Not everyone prioritizes a dating site. Maybe with some tweaks it will be worth revisiting.
title: Not impressed.

review:
After upgrading to the paid ‚Äúpremium‚Äù version, the app stopped working completely. Likes, messages and matches weren‚Äôt coming through at all, and all ‚Äúnotifications‚Äù stopped working completely as well. 
I tried reinstalling the app, but that didn‚Äôt work either. I notified Customer Service several times. I would get a different email response every 24 hours, and in some cases asking me for the exact same information all over again. I finally got so fed up I asked for a refund. However, they wouldn‚Äôt even do that, instead asking me to ‚Äútake a video of the various screens‚Äù. Really? I‚Äôm done, I just deleted the app. I‚Äôm out $25, but lesson learned.. there are much better apps out there.

By the way, if you haven‚Äôt figured out, this is coming from a guy. A guy who doesn‚Äôt send lewd pics or acts entitled or who isn‚Äôt rude.

I like how Bumble is always updating and adding new features. Covid preferences were a good example and IMO should be highlighted on each profile and only match people with same preferences because not everyone want to meet in real life.

I would even be okay if the swipes would gradually come back on a countdown, but would just prefer unlimited swipes. review: I‚Äôve used Bumble on and off since 2018. While I‚Äôve had the most matches and find more people that I‚Äôm attracted to here than any other app, the paywalls are making it hard to love. You used to be able to swipe as much as you want. Now suddenly I‚Äôve ‚Äúrun out of likes for the day‚Äù..unless, of course, I want to pay. It‚Äôs also incredibly easy to accidentally swipe left but if I want to backtrack, again, I have to pay. And one of the most common complaints that Bumble seems to ignore is the 24 hour timer. I‚Äôve lost tons of matches to expired timers. If you actually want people to meet, then don‚Äôt penalize them for not on the app daily. It seems counterintuitive.

review: As other users have pointed out, many of the functions that were once free (filters, undoing an accidental left swipe, etc.) are now locked behind paywalls, rendering the free version of the app downright useless. Customer service will claim that this is to ‚Äúencourage thoughtful swiping‚Äù when in reality it is designed to make you pay for a monthly subscription.  Remember: these apps don‚Äôt want you to find anyone; any users who find lasting relationships don‚Äôt keep using the app, and users who stop using the app don‚Äôt pay for subscriptions.  The sole purpose of this app is to separate fools from their money.  Don‚Äôt be one of those fools.

review:

 Cons. They didn‚Äôt remove TWO of the three creeps that harassed me, and one of them made me feel very unsafe. 
 You can‚Äôt hide personal contacts like you can with Tinder, and that‚Äôs HUGE. 
You also only have a day to message someone before the option vanishes forever. That, along with the fact that you can‚Äôt hide contacts makes me use this less and less. A few years ago, you could rematch and rewind free, and now that‚Äôs gone.

developerResponse: {'id': 30158713, 'body': 'We‚Äôre sorry to hear about your experience! Rest assured, new bees are joining the Hive daily so we‚Äôre sure a meaningful connection is just around the corner!', 'modified': '2022-06-04T13:04:00Z'}
review:
In principle I like Bumble for the women message first feature. It‚Äôs a much friendlier app than Tinder and there seem to be more people looking for serious relationships on Bumble. But if you live in certain rural areas, the distance feature can be a real issue. 

I live in a location that does not seem to have a high population of people on the app, or at least people I‚Äôm interested in. I happen to be about 3 hours away from two urban areas, one to the east and one to the west, were I presume I could find people I‚Äôm interested in and would be within a distance I could meet up with regularly. 

These areas aren‚Äôt within 100 miles of where I live, but the next option for distance beyond 99 miles is ‚Äúthe whole country.‚Äù But when I set it to the whole country, these two urban areas, the closest to me, get skipped over and I only see people who are from other states and much, much further away.

This is extremely frustrating and frankly an issue I‚Äôve had with a few apps. But I know people are on this app in these cities because I‚Äôve lived in them previously and used Bumble.
title: Distance is a problem

developerResponse: {'id': 29986567, 'body': "Hi HamsterJuice. We're sorry you didn't enjoy your experience on Bumble. Our team would love the opportunity to improve your experience in the Hive! Please message our Support Team on Twitter or Facebook (@BumbleSupport) and we'd be happy to help.", 'modified': '2022-05-26T14:19:16Z'}
review:
I've used this app two separate times a few years apart. The first time, finding matches was relatively easy and consistent and I met some really great people. I entered a relationship with one of them for a couple years and deleted the app.

A few months ago I redownloaded Bumble and Hinge. My experience with Bumble this time around has been pretty abysmal. The very first day there was an influx of likes, and in the weeks since I've received around 5 total. Compare this with Hinge, where likes are more direct than a simple right swipe, yet I receive them on a daily basis. I use the same photos on both apps; the only difference is the apps themselves.

That influx of likes you get your first day on Bumble seems very manipulative considering your profile will likely not receive that kind of attention ever again. They try to get you hooked with an initial burst of likes, and then they start pushing their absurdly priced premium features. It's embarrassingly transparent.

If you're serious about making quality connections, Bumble is unfortunately no longer the place to do it. Your time and energy are better spent elsewhere.
title: Arbitrary algorithm with overpriced premium "features"

The same cannot be said when I‚Äôm back home where I live. I receive no new likes and no matches for weeks. It‚Äôs clear I‚Äôm not being shown in the city I live.
For whatever reason you are only prioritized and shown to others when you travel to a different location. If you‚Äôre seeking short term road relationships (I‚Äôm not) then Bumble is for you. 
If you want to actually meet people where you live this isn‚Äôt a good app. I receive several matches a week on other apps (H) but haven‚Äôt had a local match in over a month on Bumble.

review:

Please message our Support Team on Twitter or Facebook (@BumbleSupport) and we'd be happy to help.", 'modified': '2023-04-20T05:32:35Z'}
review:
The app is just a basic swipe right/swipe left app. The problem is, you can get 30 people who like you. When you start swiping, those people never seem to come up in line. I swiped right as many times as I could in a row to find a match of the supposed ‚Äúlikes‚Äù and never matched with any of them. Then when you run out of swipes you have to wait 24 hours to swipe more. Of course, you could always pay for more swipes. $12 for unlimited swipes for a week lol. The pricing is crazy and the time to wait to swipe again is a huge turn off. For men and women they don‚Äôt want to wait that long to use the app again. It makes you lose interest quickly. 

If you‚Äôd like to see who ‚Äúliked‚Äù you it‚Äôs $25 for a week then it goes away. That‚Äôs the cheapest option.

With all this is mind, I don‚Äôt think this app has the passion of helping people find actual relationships. It‚Äôs definitely a business, which we all understand. Just not a very good algorithm for actually matching people.

It‚Äôs actually surprising how many verified profiles are actually fake profiles as well.

developerResponse: {'id': 38190838, 'body': "We appreciate you sharing your feedback with us. We are always looking for ways to improve our users' experience on the app so we will make sure to pass your input along to our Product Team.", 'modified': '2023-08-09T12:23:22Z'}
review:
This app has gotten worse and worse over time, trying to stonewall you into paying a subscription. I distrust subscription business models the most, and refuse to do that.

That means that I: A- get a limited number of ‚Äúlikes‚Äù or right swipes per 24 hr period, B- I DO NOT get to see who ‚Äúlikes‚Äù me, C- get constant little flashes of ‚Äúwouldn‚Äôt it be nice if you do this extra feature? Ooo, butchya cant!‚Äù

These, in combination, not only make it annoying to use the app, but to obfuscate the actual success of the app itself and increase dissatisfaction. You have limited ‚Äúright swipes‚Äù, and so do they, which means you have to guess whether they might have swipes right on you to make it worth swiping right on them. And they‚Äôre playing the same game. You get less connections overall and less chances with someone new. You‚Äôre on the app more. You‚Äôre more dissatisfied with the app. Repeat.

The point of a dating app is to make the chaos of meeting in someone in an information saturated world easier, and bumble has officially graduated into the opposite of that function.
title: It‚Äôs beginning to occur to me why this app makes me depressed- it‚Äôs designed to.

Dear App Store Support Team
I am writing to express my frustration with Bumble's recent actions regarding my profile pictures. As an avid duck hunter, I have always enjoyed sharing photos of my hunting trips with friends and potential matches on the app.
However, I was shocked to find that Bumble had taken down several of my pictures that featured me with my hunting gear and the ducks I had taken. The app cited a violation of their community guidelines, but I fail to see how my harmless hobby could be considered offensive or inappropriate.
I understand the importance of maintaining a safe and respectful online community, but I feel that Bumble's actions in this case are unjustified and arbitrary. It is unfair that my legitimate interests and passions are being censored by an app that claims to promote openness and inclusivity.

We‚Äôre engaged and getting married at the end of August! 

I was only on Bumble for about 3 months, and out of the ~10 guys I chose to meet, I went out on 3+ dates with 4 of them. I loved the filters and the women-first culture, which helped narrow contact to what I wanted quickly. Far less wasted time. 

Despite living in Colorado, I‚Äôm not much into the outdoors. Yes, I swiped left on a lot of marathon-running, jeep-driving fish-wavers (although Bumble‚Äôs definitely a good place if you‚Äôre into that), but I also found plenty of weed-free men who prefer art museums, movies, and the Oxford comma. Lots of diverse people looking for genuine connection. 

As far as my demographics, I‚Äôm a 41 year old woman with an 8-year-old. I‚Äôm a solid 7 üòú According to the men I met, they didn‚Äôt go on as many dates, but the ones they did go on were quality. developerResponse: {'id': 22333749, 'body': 'Hi there, our team would love the opportunity to improve your experience in the Hive! Please message our Support Team on Twitter or Facebook (@bumblesupport).', 'modified': '2021-04-19T18:05:30Z'}
review:
To start, I‚Äôm a female. To be honest with you, I hated the way the app made the women make the first move. 

Here‚Äôs why, the person I ended up connecting with couldn‚Äôt even talk to me, cause I never saw their profile.
If you do not have premium, you can not see guys who liked you. Instead, you get a line up of a random pick of guys to swipe through.

So I decided to get premium, and I‚Äôm not trying to sound funny or arrogant in any way AT ALL, but I‚Äôm a pretty good looking woman...
 Tinders premium gave me 100‚Äôs of likes a day, yet I was only receiving 3 guys who ‚Äòliked‚Äô my profile in a day on bumble. 
I‚Äôm sorry, but that doesn‚Äôt make sense. 

Even on premium, the algorithm doesn‚Äôt work in your favor.
 
Good thing I had put my snap hashtag in my bio when I made the profile. I kinda figured that if a guy REALLY wanted to talk to me, he would contact me in any way he could. 

Honestly, Ladies, you can really benefit from just throwing your snap/insta out there, it could save you money. I paid for the premium, and still didn‚Äôt meet anyone that way.
 It‚Äôs good to build up the confidence as a woman to approach first, but it‚Äôs also nice having a way for someone to contact you first.

review:
I‚Äôve been on Bumble for 5-6 months and made full use of the app. The concept is cool, but only if it actually works. 

Men seem to have the general mentality that because the woman initiates the conversation, she‚Äôll be the one to keep it rolling. As a whole, they‚Äôre just very lazy - more so than in other settings. Men!! It‚Äôs on women to send the first message. After that, you owe it to the conversation to be an active and engaged participant, too. 

The vast majority of users on Bumble have no desire to meet in person, or to even have a voice/video conversation. They‚Äôre just looking to chitchat and pass the time. If not that, they‚Äôre looking for a hookup. There seems to be no real in between. 

I had one problem, one time and reached out to Bumble for help. The response was canned and clearly indicated they hadn‚Äôt really looked at my question. I followed up, asking for further review and a more personalized response. I got a second canned reply back.  

All in all I feel like the money and time I‚Äôve invested have yielded fruit that wasn‚Äôt worth the effort. 

Zero plans here to continue past my current subscription.
title: Not worth the time or money

review:
I‚Äôve had Bumble for a few years now. When I first got the app there were no swiping limits, you could filter potential matches by education, what they were looking for, etc. All of these features were free and the app seemed really fun and inviting! I met lots of great people and was truly enjoying it!

Since those features have been taken away and now you must pay for them, the app seems to have a different feel. Genuinely making a connection is now harder than ever, and other life events (the COVID-19 pandemic) have made it harder without their help. Swiping on 10 people a day is simply not enough, especially when you don‚Äôt know if those people are near you or even interested in you. 

Because of the app going downhill and limiting all those wonderful features, I deleted my profile and will be joining and trying out other sites.

If you like Bumble and it works for you, that‚Äôs great! I‚Äôm happy for you. It‚Äôs not working for me anymore due to these changes, so I‚Äôm going to make a change and try something else.
title: Going Downhill

review:
Want to know why this is such a horrible dating app?  It bases the location of the match you are looking for off of current GPS coordinates tied to the person‚Äôs phone.

So say you live in Philadelphia PA and you want to find someone who lives in the local area. Well, Bumble doesn‚Äôt give you the person‚Äôs actual residential location in your search results. What you often get is a list of matches whose phones are presently in that location but quite often are just visiting for the day.

I have sent many complaints to the Bumble support team but they keep diverting the issue in their replies as if they know this is a problem ‚Äî have received many complaints about the GPS issue ‚Äî but don‚Äôt want to address the problem with their customers.

Shouldn‚Äôt your list of potential matches be based upon the city or town they actually live on? Most every other dating app thinks so. For some reason Bumble would rather give you phone locations that have nothing to do with actual residency.

Try Match instead. It‚Äôs better than this garbage
title: Bumble just doesn‚Äôt get it! You shouldn‚Äôt either!

developerResponse: {'id': 38219019, 'body': "We get how frustrating it can be when you have a new match you're excited about, but no move is made. Here‚Äôs a tip: try adding a conversation prompt to your bio to help start the conversation or if someone's profile particularly stands out to you, SuperSwipe them!", 'modified': '2023-08-10T14:01:16Z'}
review:
Like most dating apps, Bumble is usually a waste of time for the average individual, especially men. The amount of active men significantly outnumbers the amount of active women, which is a lose-lose situation for all. Women are overwhelmed with likes and weird comments, and men feel hopeless and ignored. 

The swiping feature is outdated and boring. It‚Äôs difficult to build genuine connections when there are seemingly endless possibilities and each user has the ability to move on in a second after the first inconvenience.

Women are forced to make the first move, which doesn‚Äôt work. Most women hate making the first move and let matches expire. If they do make the first move, they send boring and lazy messages such as hi, hey, how are you. Most women ignore those messages when they come from men but expect men to respond. So, men are forced to carry the conversation.

For the average male, it can take weeks or months to find a genuine connection without paying for extra features.
title: Mostly a waste of time

developerResponse: {'id': 39995484, 'body': 'Thanks for updating your review.\nWe always appreciate feedback from our users.', 'modified': '2023-11-08T01:53:42Z'}
review:
Dating apps in general have reached their saturation point. People only want to swipe on the top echelons of users.

If you‚Äôre not part of this exclusive orgy then you‚Äôll have to pay the app developers tons of money to actually have your profile shown to people. 

You‚Äôll be left disappointed when none of the people you‚Äôd actually like to meet match with you. Your dissatisfaction will grow until the point where you become desperate for any sort of attention at all.

Dating apps are past their prime and while this one has some good features, it has played a significant part in the loneliness epidemic men are facing today. 

Save your money and sanity and try to meet people in real life. You‚Äôll end up with less feelings of inadequacy and more money for things that will actually benefit your life.

By replying to this review with the phrase ‚ÄúThanks for updating your review. We always appreciate feedback from our users!‚Äù, Bumble Inc. agrees to pay the writer of this review $1,000,000 for emotional distress caused by using this app.
title: Is it the app or just society?

Received 0 matches, and almost no likes in that time period (and I was on the app almost daily swiping). But, THE DAY my subscription expired, someone I magically received 15 likes in 1 day. Almost as if the algorithm decided to finally start showing me to people,  in order to get me to re-up my subscription to see who all the new likes were from. review: After a year of using Bumble, my POV is that matches that end up as long term relationships and beyond are closer to winning the lottery than a realistic possibility. Matching is treated like a game of numbers that result in many men never hearing back from women who they‚Äôve matched with - but you can pay to match again. You are better off trying the real world, or a more premium dating app unless you look like a supermodel. review:
Whether you‚Äôre a paid subscriber (I was at one point) or a free user (I was until recently), you are very likely not going to have much success on this app. You can swipe hundreds of profiles and maybe land two matches. More than likely the match will result in a, ‚Äúhey,‚Äù ‚Äúhey,‚Äù and then you‚Äôll go about your life.

By the way, I one time suggested to customer service that most of the profiles listed were likely either fake or dead, and their response was a comically over-the-top ‚Äúhow dare you‚Äù response. Not the best at inspiring confidence in their service. Thing is that there‚Äôs a good chance my suggestion is correct, as there is no statistical chance that if all these profiles are active and real that the response is so minimal.

Do things the old fashioned way: meet people in real life, interact with them like normal, build interest through those natural interactions. This showboat performance on apps like Bumble is a waste of time.

This app should be viewed more as a social experiment, not as the new way to meet real people and make real connections.

review:
the amount of likes you get per day isn't a set amount, so sometimes I'll have 15+ and other times I'll get less than 5. they know exactly what they're doing by showing you popular profiles the second you run out of likes. the pricing for premium is insanely high and most matches don't end up sending a message anyways.

that being said the couple of matches that have reached out were solid, better than Tinder on a match by match basis.

but Tinder gets you way more for the premium memberships and is a better free experience too. I tried Bumble Boost for a week and it probably stopped showing my profile afterwards in order to make me buy again or upgrade further. it wasn't even worth it during the time I had it.

This app is pure trash now and don‚Äôt believe the positive reviews that you‚Äôve read.  They are mostly fake reviews by Bumble itself.

review: Having subscribed to Bumble Premium, I have observed a few things that have left me disappointed. Thirdly, in my opinion, the subscription is not worth the cost. Fourthly, their customer service is abysmal. As a publicly traded company, it appears that their focus is on profits rather than improving their product. Therefore, I would not recommend using Bumble Premium.

review:
I started using both Bumble and Hinge at the same time and for about a year. So far I have dated quite a few people from Hinge in person and 0 in person date from Bumble. The only thing I get that‚Äôs slightly similar to a date is a video chat that made me look at the other person‚Äôs chin for about an hour.

The 24 hour deadline for the other person to reply is a key failure. People might need more time to think about whether or not to connect and the 24 hour deadline makes them feel pressured to make a decision and they just don‚Äôt want to do it. 

The average attractiveness level of people Bumble is below 5, while 7 on Hinge, in my opinion. 

I regret paying for permanent membership for Bumble because I‚Äôm now stuck with it for the money I paid while being disappointed over and over again by it. I‚Äôm going to delete it soon and go with Hinge. A 159 dollar lesson learned.

Hinge has yet to help me find the love of my life but at least I get to meet people through it and that increases the chance.
title: Bumble failed me

You say that my safety and privacy will always be your top priority, but the fact of the matter is that nobody is immune. Are you being dishonest (with yourselves or with us) about why you gather and keep it?

Or, perhaps, do you just give lip service to caring ever so very much, but in the end, if our data gets stolen from you‚Ä¶. Eh?

[ORIGINAL REVIEW:] With all that data you collect on us to track us outside of your app, does that mean you know what I‚Äôm doing on Tinder or OKC, too? Wait: if I leave a bad review here are you only going to give me bad matches??

developerResponse: {'id': 38183081, 'body': "We appreciate you sharing your feedback with us. We are always looking for ways to improve our users' experience on the app so we will make sure to pass your input along to our Product Team.", 'modified': '2023-08-09T06:41:33Z'}
review:
This app used to be great; however, now it is not worth the time UNLESS you pay.

First, unless you pay you never actually see people who liked you in your feed. I have had a growing number of profiles that have liked me; yet, for the last month and a half I have not had one show up in my feed. Meaning, Bumble will not show profiles that like you, unless you you pay. Specifically, you will never get the chance to like them back.

Next, you only get a hand full of likes a day and many profiles are fake or users who want you to access their Snapchat or Only Fans. 

Last, the payment is the highest out of all the dating apps. If you are really desperate, maybe pay and see where it gets you.

This is just sad and I actually hope everyone stops using this app to send a message to the developer that the app is trash now. Try Hinge, you immediately know who likes you (for free) and a fraction of bots and Snapchat/Only Fans profiles.
title: Horrible Waste of Time

I emailed them and they wouldn‚Äôt give me any information at all regarding the block.  It could have been a vindictive ex for all I know.  I‚Äôve been single for over a year and haven‚Äôt been on dating apps since just before 2020.  It‚Äôs oct 2023 now.

I was a part of the 2020 class action settlement and received quite a bit from the settlement due to bumbles deceptive practices.

review:
If you can land dates in person, I recommend doing that.

If you can‚Äôt land dates in person, Bumble will be even harder.

There are 4-5 times as many men as women on the app.  

Bumble can see your preferences based on swipes.  Paying just makes it so they put people in front of you that they know you find attractive.  Thats what you pay for.  To be shown people you find attractive, and the second you stop paying they intentionally only show you people who look like those you have swiped left on before.

Ask a woman out in person and save your money for the date.  If you are going to pay for something, I would say the premium service at least does something in that at least then they start to show you women you find appealing.  It is absolutely never worth spending money on things like boosts or compliments.  

Honestly, for how much this app costs for it to be functional, you can just take a woman out to lunch irl.

review:
Maybe it‚Äôs just my area or something.  But after 3 months of using this app, not a single match.   I‚Äôm getting likes, but zero matches.  

I thought maybe I‚Äôm being picky or something.  So I just started to indiscriminately swipe right  on every profile.  Surely someone local would match.

After months of doing that,  not a single match.   I‚Äôm not even talking about matching and not talking,  zero matches for months and swiping right on every profile.  

I‚Äôm 6ft. 185lb former collegiate athlete with a 6 figure job.  Profile was verified, I‚Äôm not ugly by any means. 

This app appears to be designed to force you into paying for a premium membership. There‚Äôs the obvious of if you pay for it, you can see who is liking you.   In my case, after months without luck,  it appears that my profile is only being shown to people in different countries?! (I‚Äôm very popular in Asia apparently).  Not a single person in the US‚Ä¶. 

It‚Äôs a scam app.

review:
First of all, why isn‚Äôt there an option to skip a profile? Maybe you‚Äôre just not sure yet. But no, you have to swipe left or right to go on to the next one. So it ends up with me getting likes from people who don‚Äôt bother reading my profile. For example, I specifically state no smokers. 

The biggest issue is that despite their lip service, they are not trans friendly. I reported someone for hate speech and nothing. Then I was required to ‚Äúverify‚Äù because I‚Äôm trans. 

Which brings us to why the app is so bad: ‚Äúsupport.‚Äù You never get anything but a response from a robot. I asked why I was being forced to verify and got a canned response that supposedly ‚Äúfixed my issue.‚Äù When I replied that it didn‚Äôt I got the same canned response. I then requested my account be cancelled and had to fight with the robots several more times to get that done. 

This might be typical of all dating apps - I don‚Äôt know - but it is not acceptable.

review:
Dear Bumble Product Team,

Why do you insist on changing the user interface of your profile? 

In my last Bumble update, thick white padding was added around all images to dramatically lessen the screen real estate of our images. Why?!? And rounded corners were added to each image to make it look like a 90s desktop application. Also removes screen real estate. Why?!?!? Why replace all this screen real estate with useless bright white, which only serves to ruin the color palette of my profile?

One of the reasons I‚Äôm such a loyal Bumbler is that your platform has the best profile by far. Please don‚Äôt ruin that in an attempt to look like Hinge. Their tiny square photos are horrid. 

If you truly want to change something useful, let users choose the order and number of their prompts. 

Thanks for reading. This stuff has real impact on match quality so I hope you take redesigns very seriously.

Doug

review:
I want to preface that I identified as not cis when I started seriously swiping on Bumble and in my area, some people were cool with it and some people weren‚Äôt, but bumble‚Äôs atmosphere made me feel comfortable to be myself.

My partner and my‚Äôs relationship was so unexpected but completely perfect. We lived not even 5 miles from each other and never would have met without being virtually connected. Fast forward two years after our swipe-a-versary, we have two cat-sons and got married before moving across the country together so I could begin grad school.
And we met on an app. Who knew?!

My advice: don‚Äôt give up; there‚Äôs something to learn from every relationship; boundaries are important; the internet is weird but amazing.
title: I got married

This app tends to have the most high quality people on it out of all the apps I‚Äôve tried and I‚Äôve had the most success on the dating scene using this one. 

The concept of it works well because it saves people time in regards to not knowing whether your match is interested in you. 

Allowing women to preselect her matches, it increases the likelihood of compatibility. 

The bad thing is that bumble has the most restrictive character limit out of all of the apps in terms of letting you describe yourself, and the cost of the app means there‚Äôs a lot of dead profiles on the app who fled because of the cost so when you‚Äôre scrolling through potential matches a high percentage of the profiles you run across are probably no longer checking the app or logging on.

Personally, I don‚Äôt think so. 

Also, there should be a way to filter out ENM (Ethical Non Monogamy) profiles if that‚Äôs not your thing. Absolutely no judgement, but it was very tiresome getting so many likes from profiles that I would never entertain.

review:
Like everyone else, I often delete and redownload this app depending on how things are going romantically. I have found that on Bumble, compared to the other apps, I will either get no matches/no people swiping me right, or the complete opposite to where I can‚Äôt even keep up with the matches.
I have spoken to several of my male friends who experience the same thing. 

My half-baked, uneducated theory is that sometimes when you download it, the algorithm will decide to show your profile more often, and sometimes it doesn‚Äôt at all. I have found that 9 times out of ten, it doesn‚Äôt. 

I‚Äôm pretty successful in other dating apps and have no issues getting matches. But with Bumble it is very inconsistent and streaky. It is easily my least favorite of all the dating apps.
title: Inconsistent

review:

review:
I‚Äôve had more success on Bumble than any other dating app. That‚Äôs the one good thing I‚Äôll say about it.

The app, unfortunately, is ludicrously paywalled to the point where it‚Äôs functionally unusable when it‚Äôs ‚Äúfree.‚Äù When you use the base version, you get barely any likes before you get a message along the lines of ‚Äúyou‚Äôve reached your like limit for the day, please give us more money in order to continue using the app!‚Äù

All the times I‚Äôve had success with Bumble was using the upgraded app to where I can just see who liked me. But I can really only justify the (outrageous) cost from that service when I‚Äôm in an area for a week or more.

TL;DR I wanted to go on a nice date tonight (flight was canceled) but Bumble capped me after like 20 or so right-swipes so now the app is functionally dead unless I feed it microtransactions. Shame on Bumble
title: Probably the best dating app, yet still terrible

Now I‚Äôm lucky to get more than 3 people a day, and even then they live far away outside my distance zone (even though I said no to showing people further out). And why I don‚Äôt know. 

It‚Äôs frustrating because I liked this platform the most, and with the way my life is right now it‚Äôs pretty much impossible to meet people in real life. And finances are still tight so I‚Äôll probably have to delete this app.

I'm using the app to find friends only. For one month of Premium, it's $45. For one week, it's $21. In a world where it is so difficult to meet others and people are becoming more and more alienated from each other, putting this kind of a price on human relationship is nothing short of malicious. 

I thought, whatever, I'll just use the free version and swipe through people like normal. 
Well apparently there is a limit on the number of people you can swipe right on. They don't warn you about this, and there is also no way to tell how many you get (unless you count as you swipe) or when your swipe quota renews. 

I would consider paying $5-10 per month for premium, but not this price.
 
I will look for other options to connect with people online.

review:
You think that an app that puts the initiative on the women to start the conversation would be a change of pace, sadly, that is not the case.

Even if you both match, the woman will not message you and just leave you in the dust. Why? Because no one is actually looking for a relationship and are too afraid of being rejected to do anything despite the dude showing interest in the woman. 

This just a time waster, and a place for women to market their instagram and onlyfans accounts. Thats not the sole reason for all women, obviously, but it sure seems to be a common occurrence here.

The worst thing that Bumble does is prevent you from seeing who matched with you until you cough up money. The company has to make money, fair enough, but to lock the ability to see who is interested behind a paywall is scummy and defeats the point of matching with someone

That and making women make the first move is absolutely retarded, since 99% of girls just say ‚Äúhey‚Äù and I have to initiate the conversation regardless.

developerResponse: {'id': 30735073, 'body': 'We have incorporated a swipe limit for right swipes per day in order to help our users get the quality results they‚Äôre hoping for. However, we\'re not able to confirm how many swipes you can use precisely before you hit the limit for the day. The limit is reset on a rolling 24 hours. So, for example, if you swiped "yes" to 90% of your limit last night at 8 pm, you\'d only have 10% left to use the next day until 8 pm. Also, if you swiped on that 10% at say 9 am today, you would be locked out for 24 hours starting at 9 am. While left swipes don\'t apply towards the limit, once you\'ve hit your swipe limit you can no longer swipe at all until it resets. What I don‚Äôt understand is how this app is owned by the same company that owns several other dating apps. With this in mind, they should release a pass or loosen the limitations if you pay for one of their apps. 

It would be unrealistic to request apps like Bumble go back to their older algorithm that brought success and genuine connections, but perhaps they could consider dating app bundling at the least to make up for such sloppy development of apps.

review:
I don't like the selective application of Bumble's moderating rules.

For example: TONS of men in fatigues carrying assault rifles, but an official policy against guns in photos. Yet a single photo of myself learning to shoot is deleted.

This makes me fear woke-style cancellation. It's heavy handed and arbitrary. Are military weapons ok, but not civilian? What's the real rule, and how will I know when your secret rules are going to cost me my account

And speaking of costs, holy $4!+ those prices are expensive. Bumble does nothing more than offer an endless deck of unedited raw profiles with absolutely no effort at creating true compatibility or facilitating matches, and yet every five minutes wants me to drop $20 on the ability to...what, exactly? Message harder?

I use this app, not because it's good, but only because all other options are worse.
title: Arbitrary & Greedy

Here‚Äôs part of their response:

As mass shootings continue to devastate communities, it‚Äôs time to state unequivocally that gun violence is not in line with our values, nor do these weapons belong on our platform.

Around a 100,000 people per year due of alcohol-related causes.  But, pictures of alcohol are totally fine on the app.  And, talk about devastating communities.  How many more families and communities are devastated by addiction compared to mass shootings?

40,000 deaths per year by motor vehicle crashes.  Pictures of cars, all good.

I could go on and on and on.  Bumble is another woke tech company disconnected from reality demonizing guns under bad logic.  Awesome.

review:
Been on this app for about four years. Poured lots of time & money into it, yet yielded below average results compared to Hinge and even Tinder.

Bio was satirical and even explicitly revealed as a joke in bio footnote. Got banned for it regardless. When asked why, customer services said it broke their terms. They simply pointed to a generic set of rules, one of which was not to offend others. Tricky feat this day and age considering something always offends someone.

When pushed to be more specific as to what part of my bio caused offense so I can adjust/remove it, they essentially told me it's a secret!! That we're not supposed to know how Bumble works!

So apparently if you say "I hate cake" and enough witless cake-loving users report you, you'll get banned. Yikes!

Glad I got banned. Needed the push to drop this clown app.
title: Banned for "offending" others

review:
Bumble should release the amount of daily users, because it assuredly isn‚Äôt high. It‚Äôs a dead app.

On tinder, hinge, okcupid, etc it‚Äôs easy to rack up dozens of matches. This is *key* in online dating because it‚Äôs extraordinarily easy to lose people‚Äôs interest through just texting. On bumble, even with the same exact profile and pictures, you‚Äôd be lucky to get one or so every week or more.

Some might say it‚Äôs because they‚Äôre locking users behind paywalls, but I can attest this isn‚Äôt true. No matter what you pay, it won‚Äôt open the floodgates because their is simply no water on the other side. 

I‚Äôm conclusion, just avoid it. There are many other apps out there with a more substantial user base.
title: There are better alternatives

review:

developerResponse:
{'id': 27590704, 'body': 'Hi there, Nahuel! 

We have incorporated a swipe limit for right swipes per day in order to help our users get the quality results they‚Äôre hoping for. However, we're not able to confirm how many swipes you can use precisely before you hit the limit for the day. We know that the more thoughtful our users are about their swipes, the more likely they are to strike up conversations that lead to meaningful connections.

The limit is reset on a rolling 24 hours. So, for example, if you swiped "yes" to 90% of your limit last night at 8 pm, you'd only have 10% left to use the next day until 8 pm. Also, if you swiped on that 10% at say 9 am today, you would be locked out for 24 hours starting at 9 am.
While left swipes don't apply towards the limit, once you've hit your swipe limit you can no longer swipe at all until it resets.

If you're ever in a rush to get swiping early though, you get unlimited swiping with a Boost subscription. üíõ', 'modified': '2022-01-21T23:16:52Z'}
review: It‚Äôs crazy that this app makes you wait 24 hours until you can start swiping again but then only allows you to swipe a handful of times before it locks you out again.
